text: merit remains to the _Inquiry_. It was a vigorous enlargement of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: principle, which Addison had not long before timidly illustrated, that
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: critics of art seek its principles in the wrong place, so long as
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: they limit their search to poems, pictures, engravings, statues, and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: buildings, instead of first arranging the sentiments and faculties in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: man to which art makes its appeal. Addison's treatment was slight and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: merely literary; Burke dealt boldly with his subject on the base of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the most scientific psychology that was then within his reach. To
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: approach it on the psychological side at all was to make a distinct
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and remarkable advance in the method of the inquiry which he had taken
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in hand.

author: Morley, John

text: IN IRELAND--PARLIAMENT--BEACONSFIELD
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke was thirty years old before he approached even the threshold of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the arena in which he was destined to be so great a figure. He had
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: made a mark in literature, and it was to literature rather than to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: public affairs that his ambition turned. He had naturally become
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: acquainted with the brother-authors who haunted the coffee-houses in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Fleet Street; and Burke, along with his father-in-law, Dr. Nugent,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: was one of the first members of the immortal club where Johnson did
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: conversational battle with all comers. We shall, in a later chapter,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: have something to say on Burke's friendships with the followers of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: his first profession, and on the active sympathy with which he helped
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: those who were struggling into authorship. Meanwhile, the fragments
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: that remain of his own attempts in this direction are no considerable
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: contributions. His _Hints for an Essay on the Drama_ are jejune and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: infertile, when compared with the vigorous and original thought of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Diderot and Lessing at about the same period. He wrote an Account of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the European Settlements in America. His _Abridgment of the History of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: England_ comes down no further than to the reign of John. A much more
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: important undertaking than his history of the past was his design for
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: a yearly chronicle of the present. The _Annual Register_ began to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: appear in 1759. Dodsley, the bookseller of Pall Mall, provided the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: sinews of war, and he gave Burke a hundred pounds a year for his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: survey of the great events which were then passing in the world. The
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: scheme was probably born of the circumstances of the hour, for this
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: was the climax of the Seven Years' War. The clang of arms was heard in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: every quarter of the globe, and in East and West new lands were being
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: brought under the dominion of Great Britain.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: In this exciting crisis of national affairs, Burke began to be
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: acquainted with public men. In 1759 he was introduced, probably by
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Lord Charlemont, to William Gerard Hamilton, who only survives in our
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: memories by his nickname of Single-speech. As a matter of fact, he
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: made many speeches in Parliament, and some good ones, but none so
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: good as the first, delivered in a debate in 1755, in which Pitt, Fox,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Grenville, and Murray all took part, and were all outshone by the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: new luminary. But the new luminary never shone again with its first
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: brilliance. He sought Burke out on the strength of the success of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: _Vindication of Natural Society_, and he seems to have had a taste for
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: good company. Horace Walpole describes a dinner at his house in the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: summer of 1761. "There were Garrick," he says, "and a young Mr. Burke,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: who wrote a book in the style of Lord Bolingbroke, that is much
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: admired. He is a sensible man, but has not worn off his authorism yet,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and thinks there is nothing so charming as writers, and to be one. He
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: will know better one of these days." The prophecy came true in time,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: but it was Burke's passion for authorism that eventually led to a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: rupture with his first patron. Hamilton was a man of ability, but
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: selfish and unreasonable. Dr. Leland afterwards described him
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: compendiously as a sullen, vain, proud, selfish, canker-hearted,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: envious reptile.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: In 1761 Hamilton went to Ireland as secretary to Lord Halifax, and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke accompanied him in some indefinite capacity. "The absenteeism of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: her men of genius," an eminent historian has said, "was a worse wrong
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: to Ireland than the absenteeism of her landlords. If Edmund Burke had
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: remained in the country where Providence had placed him, he might have
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: changed the current of its history." [1] It is at least to be said
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: that Burke was never so absorbed in other affairs as to forget the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: peculiar interests of his native land. We have his own word, and his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: career does not belie it, that in the elation with which he was filled
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: on being elected a member of Parliament, what was first and uppermost
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in his thoughts was the hope of being somewhat useful to the place of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: his birth and education; and to the last he had in it "a dearness of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: instinct more than he could justify to reason." In fact the affairs
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of Ireland had a most important part in Burke's life at one or two
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: critical moments, and this is as convenient a place as we are likely
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: to find for describing in a few words what were the issues. The brief
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: space can hardly be grudged in an account of a great political writer,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: for Ireland had furnished the chief ordeal, test, and standard of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: English statesmen.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: [Footnote 1: Fronde's _Ireland_, ii. 214.]
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Ireland in the middle of the eighteenth century was to England just
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: what the American colonies would have been, if they had contained,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: besides the European settlers, more than twice their number of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: unenslaved negroes. After the suppression of the great rebellion of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Tyrconnel by William of Orange, nearly the whole of the land was
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: confiscated, the peasants were made beggars and outlaws, the Penal
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Laws against the Catholics were enacted and enforced, and the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: grand reign of Protestant Ascendancy began in all its vileness and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: completeness. The Protestants and landlords were supreme; the peasants
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and the Catholics were prostrate in despair. The Revolution brought
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: about in Ireland just the reverse of what it effected in England. Here
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: it delivered the body of the nation from the attempted supremacy of a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: small sect. There it made a small sect supreme over the body of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: nation. "It was, to say the truth," Burke wrote, "not a revolution but
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: a conquest," and the policy of conquest was treated as the just and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: normal system of government. The last conquest of England was in the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: eleventh century. The last conquest of Ireland was at the very end of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the seventeenth.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Sixty years after the event, when Burke revisited Ireland, some
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: important changes had taken place. The English settlers of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: beginning of the century had formed an Irish interest. They had become
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Anglo-Irish, just as the colonists still further west had formed a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: colonial interest and become Anglo-American. The same conduct on
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the part of the mother country promoted the growth of these hostile
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: interests in both cases. The commercial policy pursued by England
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: towards America was identical with that pursued towards Ireland. The
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: industry of the Anglo-Irish traders was restricted, their commerce
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and even their production fettered, their prosperity checked, for the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: benefit of the merchants of Manchester and Bristol. _Crescit Roma
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Albae ruinis_. "The bulk of the people," said Stone, the Primate, "are
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: not regularly either lodged, clothed, or fed; and those things which
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in England are called necessaries of life, are to us only accidents,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and we can, and in many places do, subsist without them." On the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: other hand, the peasantry had gradually taken heart to resent their
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: spoliation and attempted extirpation, and in 1761 their misery
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: under the exactions of landlords and a church which tried to spread
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Christianity by the brotherly agency of the tithe-proctor, gave birth
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: to Whiteboyism--a terrible spectre, which, under various names and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: with various modifications, has ridden Ireland down to our own time.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke saw the Protestant traders of the dependency the victims of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the colonial and commercial system; the Catholic landowners legally
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: dispossessed by the operation of the penal laws; the Catholic
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: peasantry deeply penetrated with an insurgent and vindictive spirit;
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and the Imperial Government standing very much aloof, and leaving the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: country to the tender mercies of the Undertakers and some Protestant
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: churchmen. The Anglo-Irish were bitterly discontented with the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: mother country; and the Catholic native Irish were regarded by their
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Protestant oppressors with exactly that combination of intense
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: contempt and loathing, and intense rage and terror, which their
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: American counterpart would have divided between the Negro and the Red
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Indian. To the Anglo-Irish the native peasant was as odious as the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: first, and as terrible as the second. Even at the close of the century
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke could declare that the various descriptions of the people were
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: kept as much apart as if they were not only separate nations, but
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: separate species. There were thousands, he says, who had never talked
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: to a Roman Catholic in their whole lives, unless they happened to talk
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: to a gardener's workman or some other labourer of the second or third
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: order; while a little time before this they were so averse to have
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: them near their persons, that they would not employ even those who
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: could never find their way beyond the stables. Chesterfield, a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: thoroughly impartial and just observer, said in 1764 that the poor
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: people in Ireland were used worse than negroes by their masters and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the middlemen. We should never forget that in the transactions with
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the English Government during the eighteenth century, the people
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: concerned were not the Irish, but the Anglo-Irish, the colonists
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of 1691. They were an aristocracy, as Adam Smith said of them, not
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: founded in the natural and respectable distinctions of birth and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: fortune, but in the most odious of all distinctions, those of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: religious and political prejudices--distinctions which, more than any
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: other, animate both the insolence of the oppressors and the hatred and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: indignation of the oppressed.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: The directions in which Irish improvement would move were clear from
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the middle of the century to men with much less foresight than
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke had. The removal of all commercial restrictions, either by
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Independence or Union, on the one hand, and the gradual emancipation
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of the Catholics, on the other, were the two processes to which every
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: consideration of good government manifestly pointed. The first proved
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: a much shorter and simpler process than the second. To the first
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the only obstacle was the blindness and selfishness of the English
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: merchants. The second had to overcome the virulent opposition of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: tyrannical Protestant faction in Ireland, and the disgraceful but
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: deep-rooted antipathies of the English nation. The history of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: relation between the mother country and her dependency during Brake's
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: life, may be characterised as a commercial and legislative struggle
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: between the imperial government and the Anglo-Irish interest, in which
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: each side for its own convenience, as the turn served, drew support
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: from the Catholic majority.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: A Whiteboy outbreak, attended by the usual circumstances of disorder
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and violence, took place while Burke was in Ireland. It suited the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: interests of faction to represent these commotions as the symptoms of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: a deliberate rebellion. The malcontents were represented as carrying
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: on treasonable correspondence, sometimes with Spain and sometimes
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: with France; they were accused of receiving money and arms from their
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: foreign sympathisers, and of aiming at throwing off the English rule.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke says that he had means and the desire of informing himself to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the bottom upon the matter, and he came strongly to the conclusion
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: that this was not a true view of what had happened. What had happened
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: was due, he thought, to no plot, but to superficial and fortuitous
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: circumstances. He consequently did not shrink from describing it as
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: criminal, that the king's Catholic subjects in Ireland should have
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: been subjected, on no good grounds, to harassing persecution, and that
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: numbers of them should have been ruined in fortune, imprisoned, tried,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and capitally executed for a rebellion which was no rebellion at all.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: The episode is only important as illustrating the strong and manly
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: temper in which Burke, unlike too many of his countrymen with fortunes
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: to make by English favour, uniformly considered the circumstances of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: his country. It was not until a later time that he had an opportunity
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of acting conspicuously on her behalf, but whatever influence he came
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: to acquire with his party was unflinchingly used against the cruelty
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of English prejudice.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke appears to have remained in Ireland for two years (1761-63). In
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: 1763 Hamilton, who had found him an invaluable auxiliary, procured for
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: him, principally with the aid of the Primate Stone, a pension of three
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: hundred pounds a year from the Irish Treasury. In thanking him for
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: this service, Burke proceeded to bargain that the obligation should
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: not bind him to give to his patron the whole of his time. He insisted
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: on being left with a discreet liberty to continue a little work which
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: he had as a rent-charge upon his thoughts. Whatever advantages he had
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: acquired, he says, had been due to literary reputation, and he could
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: only hope for a continuance of such advantages on condition of doing
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: something to keep the same reputation alive. What this literary design
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: was, we do not know with certainty. It is believed to have been a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: history of England, of which, as I have said, a fragment remains.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Whatever the work may have been, it was an offence to Hamilton. With
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: an irrational stubbornness, that may well astound us when we think of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the noble genius that he thus wished to confine to paltry personal
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: duties, he persisted that Burke should bind himself to his service for
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: life, and to the exclusion of other interests. "To circumscribe my
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: hopes," cried Burke, "to give up even the possibility of liberty, to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: annihilate myself for ever!" He threw up the pension, which he had
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: held for two years, and declined all further connection with Hamilton,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: whom he roundly described as an infamous scoundrel. "Six of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: best years of my life he took me from every pursuit of my literary
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: reputation, or of improvement of my fortune.... In all this time you
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: may easily conceive how much I felt at seeing myself left behind
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: by almost all of my contemporaries. There never was a season more
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: favourable for any man who chose to enter into the career of public
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: life; and I think I am not guilty of ostentation in supposing my own
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: moral character and my industry, my friends and connections, when Mr.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Hamilton first sought my acquaintance, were not at all inferior to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: those of several whose fortune is at this day upon a very different
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: footing from mine."
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: It was not long before a more important opening offered itself, which
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: speedily brought Burke into the main stream of public life. In the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: summer of 1765 a change of ministry took place. It was the third since
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the king's accession five years ago. First, Pitt had been disgraced,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and the old Duke of Newcastle dismissed. Then Bute came into power,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: but Bute quailed before the storm of calumny and hate which his Scotch
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: nationality, and the supposed source of his power over the king, had
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: raised in every town in England. After Lord Bute, George Grenville
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: undertook the Government. Before he had been many months in office,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: he had sown the seeds of war in the colonies, wearied Parliament,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and disgusted the king. In June 1765 Grenville was dismissed. With
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: profound reluctance the king had no other choice than to summon Lord
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Rockingham, and Lord Rockingham, in a happy moment for himself and his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: party, was induced to offer Burke a post as his private secretary.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: A government by country gentlemen is too apt to be a government of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: ignorance, and Lord Rockingham was without either experience or
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: knowledge. He felt, or friends felt for him, the advantage of having
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: at his side a man who was chiefly known as an author in the service
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of Dodsley, and as having conducted the _Annual Register_ with great
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: ability, but who even then was widely spoken of as nothing less than
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: an encyclopaedia of political knowledge.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: It is commonly believed that Burke was commended to Lord Rockingham by
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: William Fitzherbert. Fitzherbert was President of the Board of Trade
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in the new government, but he is more likely to be remembered as Dr.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Johnson's famous example of the truth of the observation, that a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: think worse of himself by being his rival, seemed always to listen,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: did not oblige you to hear much from him, and did not oppose what
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: you said. Besides Fitzherbert's influence, we have it on Burke's own
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

text: of state. There must have been unpleasant rumours afloat as to the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: worth. Meanwhile, it is enough to say that the old Duke of Newcastle
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: hurried to the new premier, and told him the appointment would never
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: do; that the new secretary was not only an Irish adventurer, which was

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: sent for Burke, and repeated to him what he had heard. Burke warmly
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: denounced the truthlessness of the Duke's tattle. He insisted that

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: which the disappointed minister accused his successors of ruining the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: country. Burke, in answering the charge, showed a grasp of commercial
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and fiscal details at least equal to that of Grenville himself, then
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: trade and resources. To this easy mastery of the special facts of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: discussion, Burke added the far rarer art of lighting them up by broad
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: principles, and placing himself and his readers at the highest and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: If Burke had been the Irish adventurer that his enemies described, he
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

text: while to leave no answer, is somehow a triumph of their own learning
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and dialectic.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: In 1769 Burke purchased a house and lands known as Gregories, in the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: parishes of Penn and Beaconsfield, in the county of Bucks. It has
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: than a few months before, was still contented to earn an extra hundred
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: pounds a year by writing for Dodsley, should now have launched out as
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: thousand pounds, which could not be kept up on less than two thousand
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: five hundred a year, and of which the returns did not amount to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of this great man's high character an unpleasant shock. It is alleged
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: that he had plunged into furious gambling in East India stock. The
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: charge was current at the time, and it was speedily revived when
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke's abandonment of his party, after the French Revolution, exposed
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: him to a thousand attacks of reckless and uncontrolled virulence. It
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: has been stirred by one or two pertinacious critics nearer our own
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: time, and none of the biographers have dealt with the perplexities
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of the matter as they ought to have done. Nobody, indeed, has ever
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: evidence that he was a holder of the stock, and no more. But what is

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: intimate if not his kinsman, and Lord Verney, his political patron,

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: were unable to pay their differences; and that in the year when Edmund
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke bought Gregories, the other three were utterly ruined, two of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: them beyond retrieval. Again it is clear that, after this, Richard
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: were disputed by the Government as questionable and dishonest; and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: day, to be deeply interested in land at Saint Vincent's. But there
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: is no evidence. What cannot be denied is that an unpleasant taint of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: whole connection, and that the adventures invariably came to an
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: unlucky end.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Whether Edmund Burke and William Burke were relations or not, and if
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: their boyish years. "Looking back to the course of my life," he wrote
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in 1771, "I remember no one considerable benefit in the whole of it
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: which I did not, mediately or immediately, derive from William Burke."
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: There is nothing intrinsically incredible, therefore, considering this
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: In a letter to Shackleton (May 1, 1768), Burke gave the following
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: account of what he had done:--"I have made a push," he says, "with all

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: from London. It is a place exceedingly pleasant; and I propose, God
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: willing, to become a farmer in good earnest. You, who are classical,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: purchase of Beaconsfield have been made tolerably clear. The price was
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: before the purchase made Edmund his residuary legatee, and it is
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: bond.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: The purchase after all was the smallest part of the matter, and it

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

text: down to 1788. But when all these resources have been counted up, we
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: cannot but see the gulf of a great yearly deficit. The unhappy truth
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: generosity which is not the less honourable to him for having been so

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: destroyed.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: We may indeed wish from the bottom of our hearts that all this had

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: memory, may be justly reminded that when Pitt died, after drawing the

author: Morley, John

title: Burke

text: forty thousand pounds. Burke, as I have said elsewhere, had none of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: pettiness. At least, every creditor was paid in good time, and nobody

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

text: they almost forgot the great colossus of ivory and gold, Phidias's

author: Morley, John

text: statue of Zeus, which they had come to see, and which stood in all its

author: Morley, John

text: glory and power before their perturbed and foolish vision.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: There have been few men in history with whom personal objects counted
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

text: which all these irregularities were the distempered incidents. The

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

text: between Montesquieu's principles and Burke's, but the student of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: _Esprit des Lois_ will recognise its influence in every one of Burke's

author: Morley, John

text: So far as immediate events were concerned, Burke was quick to discern
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: their true interpretation. As has been already said, he attributed to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the king and his party a deliberateness of system which probably had
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: no real existence in their minds. The king intended to reassert the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: old right of choosing his own ministers. George II. had made strenuous
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: but futile endeavours to the same end. His son, the father of George
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: III., Frederick, Prince of Wales, as every reader of Dodington's Diary
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: will remember, was equally bent on throwing off the yoke of the great
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Whig combinations, and making his own cabinets. George III. was only
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: continuing the purpose of his father and his grandfather; and there is
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: no reason to believe that he went more elaborately to work to obtain
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: his ends.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: It is when he leaves the artifices of a cabal, and strikes down below
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the surface to the working of deep social forces, that we feel the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: breadth and power of Burke's method. "I am not one of those," he
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: began, "who think that the people are never wrong. They have been so,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: frequently and outrageously, both in other countries and in this. But
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: I do say that _in all disputes between them and their rulers, the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: presumption is at least upon a par in favour of the people_." Nay,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: experience perhaps justifies him in going further. When popular
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: discontents are prevalent, something has generally been found amiss in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the constitution or the administration. "The people have no interest
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in disorder. When they go wrong, it is their error, and not their
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: crime." And then he quotes the famous passage from the Memoirs of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Sully, which both practical politicians and political students
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: should bind about their necks, and write upon the tables of their
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: hearts:--"The revolutions that come to pass in great states are not
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the result of chance, nor of popular caprice.... As for the populace,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: it is never from a passion for attack that it rebels, but from
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: impatience of suffering."
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: What really gives its distinction to the _Present Discontents_ is not
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: its plea for indulgence to popular impatience, nor its plea for the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: superiority of government by aristocracy, but rather the presence in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: it of the thought of Montesquieu and his school, of the necessity
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of studying political phenomena in relation, not merely to forms of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: government and law, but in relation to whole groups of social facts
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: which give to law and government the spirit that makes them workable.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Connected with this, is a particularly wide interpretation and a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: particularly impressive application of the maxims of expediency,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: because a wide conception of the various interacting elements of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: a society naturally extends the considerations which a balance of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: expediencies will include. Hence, in time, there came a strong
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and lofty ideal of the true statesman, his breadth of vision, his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: flexibility of temper, his hardly measurable influence. These are the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: principal thoughts in the _Discontents_ to which that tract owes its
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: permanent interest. "Whatever original energy," says Burke, in one
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: place, "may be supposed either in force or regulation, the operation
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of both is in truth merely instrumental. Nations are governed by the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: same methods, and on the same principles, by which an individual
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: without authority is often able to govern those who are his equals
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: or superiors; by a knowledge of their temper, and by a judicious
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: management of it.... The laws reach but a very little way. Constitute
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Government how you please, infinitely the greater part of it must
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: depend upon the exercise of powers, which are left at large to the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: prudence and uprightness of ministers of state. Even all the use and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: potency of the laws depends upon them. Without them, your Commonwealth
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: is no better than _a scheme upon paper; and not a living, active,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: effective constitution_." Thus early in his public career had Burke
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: seized that great antithesis which he so eloquently laboured in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the long and ever memorable episode of his war against the French
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Revolution: the opposition between artificial arrangements in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: politics, and a living, active, effective organisation, formed by what
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: he calls elsewhere in the present tract the natural strength of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: kingdom, and suitable to the temper and mental habits of the people.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: When he spoke of the natural strength of the kingdom, he gave no
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: narrow or conventional account of it. He included in the elements
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of that strength, besides the great peers and the leading landed
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: gentlemen, the opulent merchants and manufacturers, and the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: substantial yeomanry. Contrasted with the trite versions of Government
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: as fixed in King, Lords, and Commons, this search for the real organs
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of power was going to the root of the matter in a spirit at once
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: thoroughly scientific and thoroughly practical. Burke had, by the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: speculative training to which he had submitted himself in dealing with
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Bolingbroke, prepared his mind for a complete grasp of the idea of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the body politic as a complex growth, a manifold whole, with closely
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: interdependent relations among its several parts and divisions. It
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: was this conception from which his conservatism sprang. Revolutionary
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: politics have one of their sources in the idea that societies are
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: capable of infinite and immediate modifications, without reference to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the deep-rooted conditions that have worked themselves into every part
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of the social structure. The same opposition of the positive to the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: doctrinaire spirit is to be observed in the remarkable vindication of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Party, which fills the last dozen pages of the pamphlet, and which
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: is one of the most courageous of all Burke's deliverances. Party
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: combination is exactly one of those contrivances which, as it might
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: seem, a wise man would accept for working purposes, but about which
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: he would take care to say as little as possible. There appears to be
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: something revolting to the intellectual integrity and self-respect of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the individual in the systematic surrender of his personal action,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: interest, and power, to a political connection in which his own
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: judgment may never once be allowed to count for anything. It is like
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the surrender of the right of private judgment to the authority of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Church, but with its nakedness not concealed by a mystic doctrine.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Nothing is more easy to demolish by the bare logical reason. But Burke
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: cared nothing about the bare logical reason, until it had been
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: clothed in convenience and custom, in the affections on one side, and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: experience on the other. Not content with insisting that for some
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: special purpose of the hour, "when bad men combine, the good must
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: associate," he contended boldly for the merits of fidelity to party
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: combination in itself. Although Burke wrote these strong pages as a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: reply to Bolingbroke, who had denounced party as an evil, they remain
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: as the best general apology that has ever been offered for that
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: principle of public action, against more philosophic attacks than
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Bolingbroke's. Burke admitted that when he saw a man acting a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: desultory and disconnected part in public life with detriment to his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: fortune, he was ready to believe such a man to be in earnest, though
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: not ready to believe him to be right. In any case he lamented to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: see rare and valuable qualities squandered away without any public
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: utility. He admitted, moreover, on the other hand, that people
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: frequently acquired in party confederacies a narrow, bigoted, and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: proscriptive spirit. "But where duty renders a critical situation
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: a necessary one, it is our business to keep free from the evils
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: attendant upon it, and not to fly from the situation itself. It is
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: surely no very rational account of a man that he has always acted
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: right, but has taken special care to act in such a manner that his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: endeavours could not possibly be productive of any consequence....
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: When men are not acquainted with each other's, principles, nor
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: among them; it is evidently impossible that they can act a public part
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: with uniformity, perseverance, or efficacy."
title: Burke

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke

author: Morley, John

title: Burke

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke

title: Burke

title: Burke

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke

title: Burke

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the affairs of Wilkes and the Middlesex election, was followed, as
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke

title: Burke

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke

author: Morley, John

text: Through this long and eventful period, Burke's was as the voice of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

text: and I do authorise you to say so." Nor was this the only kind of
title: Burke

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Certainly, gentlemen, it ought to be the happiness and glory of
title: Burke

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

text: constituents. Their wishes ought to have great weight with him;
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke

text: sacrifice to you, to any man, or to any set of men living. Your
title: Burke

author: Morley, John

text: and he betrays, instead of serving you, if he sacrifices it to
title: Burke

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke

text: superior. But government and legislation are matters of reason and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: judgment, and not of inclination; and what sort of reason is that
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the conclusion are perhaps three hundred miles distant from
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: those who hear the arguments?... _Authoritative_ instructions,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: _mandates_ issued, which the member is bound blindly and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: implicitly to obey, to vote, and to argue for, though contrary to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the clearest convictions of his judgment and conscience--these are
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Constitution.[1]
