text: Court of its chief implements of corruption, and protecting the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: representative against his chief motive in selling his country. He
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: conceived that he would thus be promoting a far more infallible means
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: than any scheme of electoral reform could have provided, for reviving
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the integrity and independence of the House of Commons. In his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: eyes, the evil resided not in the constituencies, but in their
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: representatives; not in the small number of the one, but in the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: smaller integrity of the other. The evil did not stop where it began.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: It was not merely that the sinister motive, thus engendered in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the minds of too lax and facile men, induced them to betray their
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: legislative trust, and barter their own uprightness and the interests
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of the State. The acquisition of one of these nefarious bribes meant
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: much more than a sinister vote. It called into existence a champion of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: every inveterate abuse that weighed on the resources of the country.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: There is a well-known passage in the speech on Economical Reform, in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: which the speaker shows what an insurmountable obstacle Lord Talbot
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: had found in his attempt to carry out certain reforms in the royal
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: household, in the fact that the turnspit of the king's kitchen was a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: member of Parliament. "On that rock his whole adventure split,--his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: whole scheme of economy was dashed to pieces; his department
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: became more expensive than ever; the Civil List debt accumulated."
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Interference with the expenses of the household meant interference
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: with the perquisites or fees of this legislative turnspit, and the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: rights of sinecures were too sacred to be touched. In comparison with
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: them, it counted for nothing that the king's tradesmen went unpaid,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and became bankrupt; that the judges were unpaid; that the justice of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the kingdom bent and gave way; the foreign ministers remained inactive
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and unprovided; the system of Europe was dissolved; the chain of our
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: alliances was broken; all the wheels of Government at home and abroad
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: were stopped. _The king's turnspit was a member of Parliament_.[1]
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: This office and numbers of others exactly like it, existed solely
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: because the House of Commons was crowded with venal men. The post of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: royal scullion meant a vote that could be relied upon under every
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: circumstance and in all emergencies. And each incumbent of such an
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: office felt his honour and interests concerned in the defence of all
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: other offices of the same scandalous description. There was thus
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: maintained a strong standing army of expensive, lax, and corrupting
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: officials.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: [Footnote 1: The Civil List at this time comprehended a great number
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of charges, such as those of which Burke speaks, that had nothing
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: to do with the sovereign personally. They were slowly removed, the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: judicial and diplomatic charges being transferred on the accession of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: William IV.] The royal household was a gigantic nest of costly jobbery
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and purposeless profusion. It retained all "the cumbrous charge of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: a Gothic establishment," though all its usage and accommodation had
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: "shrunk into the polished littleness of modern elegance." The outlay
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: was enormous. The expenditure on the court tables only was a thing
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: unfathomable. Waste was the rule in every branch of it. There was an
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: office for the Great Wardrobe, another office of the Robes, a third
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of the Groom of the Stole. For these three useless offices there
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: were three useless treasurers. They all laid a heavy burden on the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: taxpayer, in order to supply a bribe to the member of Parliament.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: The plain remedy was to annihilate the subordinate treasuries. "Take
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: away," was Burke's demand, "the whole establishment of detail in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the household: the Treasurer, the Comptroller, the Cofferer of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Household, the Treasurer of the Chamber, the Master of the Household,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the whole Board of Green Cloth; a vast number of subordinate offices
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in the department of the Steward of the Household; the whole
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: establishment of the Great Wardrobe; the Removing Wardrobe; the Jewel
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Office; the Robes; the Board of Works." The abolition of this confused
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and costly system would not only diminish expense and promote
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: efficiency; it would do still more excellent service in destroying the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: roots of parliamentary corruption. "Under other governments a question
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of expense is only a question of economy, and it is nothing more;
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: with us, in every question of expense, there is always a mixture of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: constitutional considerations."
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Places and pensions, though the worst, were not by any means the only
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: stumbling-block in the way of pure and well-ordered government. The
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: administration of the estates of the Crown,--the Principality, the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Duchy of Cornwall, the Duchy of Lancaster, the County Palatine
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of Chester,--was an elaborate system of obscure and unprofitable
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: expenditure. Wales had to herself eight judges, while no more than
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: twelve sufficed to perform the whole business of justice in England, a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: country ten times as large and a hundred times as opulent. Wales,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and each of the duchies, had its own exchequer. Every one of these
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: principalities, said Burke, has the apparatus of a kingdom, for the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: jurisdiction over a few private estates; it has the formality and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: charge of the Exchequer of Great Britain, for collecting the rents of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: a country squire. They were the field, in his expressive phrase,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of mock jurisdictions and mimic revenues, of difficult trifles and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: laborious fooleries. "It was but the other day that that pert factious
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: fellow, the Duke of Lancaster, presumed to fly in the face of his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: liege lord, our gracious sovereign--presumed to go to law with the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: king. The object is neither your business nor mine. Which of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: parties got the better I really forget. The material point is that the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: suit cost about L15,000. But as the Duke of Lancaster is but agent of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Duke Humphrey, and not worth a groat, our sovereign was obliged to pay
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the costs of both." The system which involved these costly absurdities
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke proposed entirely to abolish. In the same spirit he wished to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: dispose of the Crown lands and the forest lands, which it was for the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: good of the community, not less than of the Crown itself, to throw
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: into the hands of private owners.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: One of the most important of these projected reforms, and one which
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: its author did not flinch from carrying out two years later to his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: own loss, related to the office of Paymaster. This functionary was
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: accustomed to hold large balances of the public money in his own hands
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and for his own profit, for long periods, owing to a complex system of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: accounts which was so rigorous as entirely to defeat its own object.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: The paymaster could not, through the multiplicity of forms and the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: exaction of impossible conditions, get a prompt acquittance. The
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: audit sometimes did not take place for years after the accounts were
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: virtually closed. Meanwhile the money accumulated in his hands, and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: its profits were his legitimate perquisite. Lord Holland, or his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: representatives, held the balances of his office from 1765, when he
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: retired, until 1778, when they were audited. During this time he
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: realised, as the interest on the use of these balances, nearly two
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: hundred and fifty thousand pounds. Burke diverted these enormous gains
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: into the coffers of the State. He fixed the paymaster's salary at four
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: thousand pounds a year, and was himself the first person who accepted
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the curtailed income.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Not the most fervid or brilliant of Burke's pieces, yet the speech on
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Economical Reform is certainly not the least instructive or impressive
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of them. It gives a suggestive view of the relations existing at that
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: time between the House of Commons and the Court. It reveals the narrow
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and unpatriotic spirit of the king and the ministers, who could resist
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: proposals so reasonable in themselves, and so remedial in their
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: effects, at a time when the nation was suffering the heavy and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: distressing burdens of the most disastrous war that our country has
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: ever carried on. It is especially interesting as an illustration of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: its author's political capacity. At a moment when committees and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: petitions and great county meetings showed how thoroughly the national
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: anger was roused against the existing system, Burke came to the front
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of affairs with a scheme, of which the most striking characteristic
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: proved to be that it was profoundly temperate. Bent on the extirpation
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of the system, he had no ill-will towards the men who had happened
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: to flourish in it. "I never will suffer," he said, "any man or
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: description of men to suffer from errors that naturally have grown
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: out of the abusive constitution of those offices which I propose to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: regulate. If I cannot reform with equity, I will not reform at all."
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Exasperated as he was by the fruitlessness of his opposition to a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: policy which he detested from the bottom of his soul, it would have
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: been little wonderful if he had resorted to every weapon of his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: unrivalled rhetorical armoury, in order to discredit and overthrow the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: whole scheme of government. Yet nothing could have been further from
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: his mind than any violent or extreme idea of this sort. Many years
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: afterwards, he took credit to himself less for what he did on this
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: occasion than for what he prevented from being done. People were ready
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: for a new modelling of the two Houses of Parliament, as well as for
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: grave modifications of the Prerogative. Burke resisted this temper
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: unflinchingly. "I had," he says, "a state to preserve, as well as a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: state to reform. I had a people to gratify, but not to inflame or to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: mislead." He then recounts without exaggeration the pains and caution
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: with which he sought reform, while steering clear of innovation. He
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: heaved the lead every inch of way he made. It is grievous to think
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: that a man who could assume such an attitude at such a time, who could
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: give this kind of proof of his skill in the great, the difficult art
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of governing, only held a fifth-rate office for some time less than a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: twelvemonth.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: The year of the project of Economic Reform (1780) is usually taken as
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the date when Burke's influence and repute were at their height. He
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: had not been tried in the fire of official responsibility, and his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: impetuosity was still under a degree of control which not long
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: afterwards was fatally weakened by an over-mastering irritability of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: constitution. High as his character was now in the ascendant, it was
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in the same year that Burke suffered the sharp mortification of losing
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: his seat at Bristol. His speech before the election is one of the best
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: known of all his performances; and it well deserves to be so, for it
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: is surpassed by none in gravity, elevation, and moral dignity. We
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: can only wonder that a constituency which could suffer itself to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: be addressed on this high level, should have allowed the small
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: selfishness of local interest to weigh against such wisdom and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: nobility. But Burke soon found in the course of his canvas that he had
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: no chance, and he declined to go to the poll. On the previous day one
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of his competitors had fallen down dead. "_What shadows we are_" said
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke, "_and what shadows we pursue!_"
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: In 1782 Lord North's government came to an end, and the king "was
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: pleased," as Lord North quoted with jesting irony from the _Gazette_,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: to send for Lord Rockingham, Charles Fox, and Lord Shelburne. Members
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: could hardly believe their own eyes, as they saw Lord North and the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: members of a government which had been in place for twelve years, now
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: lounging on the opposition benches in their greatcoats, frocks, and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: boots, while Fox and Burke shone in the full dress that was then
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: worn by ministers, and cut unwonted figures with swords, lace, and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: hair-powder. Sheridan was made an under-secretary of state, and to the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: younger Pitt was offered his choice of various minor posts, which he
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: haughtily refused. Burke, to whom on their own admission the party
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: owed everything, was appointed Paymaster of the Forces, with a salary
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of four thousand pounds a year. His brother, Richard Burke, was
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: made Secretary of the Treasury. His son Richard was named to be his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: father's deputy at the Pay-Office, with a salary of five hundred
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: pounds.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: This singular exclusion from cabinet office of the most powerful
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: genius of the party has naturally given rise to abundant criticism
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: ever since. It will be convenient to say what there is to be said on
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: this subject, in connection with the events of 1788 (below, p. 200),
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: because there happens to exist some useful information about the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: ministerial crisis of that year, which sheds a clearer light upon the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: arrangements of six years before. Meanwhile it is enough to say that
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke himself had most reasonably looked to some higher post. There
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: is the distinct note of the humility of mortified pride in a letter
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: written in reply to some one who had applied to him for a place. "You
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: have been misinformed," he says; "I make no part of the ministerial
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: arrangement. Something in the official line may possibly be thought
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: fit for my measure." Burke knew that his position in the country
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: entitled him to something above the official line. In a later year,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: when he felt himself called upon to defend his pension, he described
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: what his position was in the momentous crisis from 1780 to 1782, and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke's habitual veraciousness forbids us to treat the description as
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in any way exaggerated. "By what accident it matters not," he says,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: "nor upon what desert, but just then, and in the midst of that hunt of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: obloquy which has ever pursued me with a full cry through life, I
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: had obtained a very full degree of public confidence.... Nothing to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: prevent disorder was omitted; when it appeared, nothing to subdue it
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: was left uncounselled nor unexecuted, as far as I could prevail. At
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the time I speak of, and having a momentary lead, so aided and so
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: encouraged, and as a feeble instrument in a mighty hand--I do not say
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: I saved my country--I am sure I did my country important service.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: There were few indeed that did not at that time acknowledge it--and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: that time was thirteen years ago. It was but one view, that no man in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the kingdom better deserved an honourable provision should be made for
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: [Footnote 1: _Letter to a Noble Lord._]
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: We have seen that Burke had fixed the paymaster's salary at four
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: thousand pounds, and had destroyed the extravagant perquisites. The
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: other economical reforms which were actually effected fell short by
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: a long way of those which Burke had so industriously devised and so
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: forcibly recommended. In 1782, while Burke declined to spare his own
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: office, the chief of the cabinet conferred upon Barre a pension of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: over three thousand a year; above ten times the amount, as has been
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: said, which, in Lord Rockingham's own judgment, as expressed in the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: new Bill, ought henceforth to be granted to any one person whatever.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: This shortcoming, however, does not detract from Burke's merit. He was
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: not responsible for it. The eloquence, ingenuity, diligence, above
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: all, the sagacity and the justice of this great effort of 1780, are
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: none the less worthy of our admiration and regard because, in 1782,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: his chiefs, partly perhaps out of a new-born deference for the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: feelings of their royal master, showed that the possession of office
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: had sensibly cooled the ardent aspirations proper to Opposition.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: The events of the twenty months between the resignation of Lord North
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: (1782) and the accession of Pitt to the office of Prime Minister
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: (December 1783) mark an important crisis in political history, and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: they mark an important crisis in Burke's career and hopes. Lord
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Rockingham had just been three months in office, when he died (July
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: 1782). This dissolved the bond that held the two sections of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: ministry together, and let loose a flood of rival ambitions and sharp
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: animosities. Lord Shelburne believed himself to have an irresistible
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: claim to the chief post in the administration; among other reasons,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: because he might have had it before Lord Rockingham three months
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: earlier, if he had so chosen. The king supported him, not from any
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: partiality to his person, but because he dreaded and hated Charles
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Fox. The character of Shelburne is one of the perplexities of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: time. His views on peace and free trade make him one of the precursors
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of the Manchester School. No minister was so well informed as to the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: threads of policy in foreign countries. He was the intimate or the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: patron of men who now stand out as among the first lights of that
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: time--of Morellet, of Priestley, of Bentham. Yet a few months of power
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: seem to have disclosed faults of character, which left him without a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: single political friend, and blighted him with irreparable discredit.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Fox, who was now the head of the Rockingham section of the Whigs, had,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: before the death of the late premier, been on the point of refusing to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: serve any longer with Lord Shelburne, and he now very promptly refused
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: to serve under him. When Parliament met after Rockingham's death,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: gossips noticed that Fox and Burke continued, long after the Speaker
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: had taken the chair, to walk backwards and forwards in the Court of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Bequests, engaged in earnest conversation. According to one story,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke was very reluctant to abandon an office whose emoluments were
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: as convenient to him as to his spendthrift colleague. According
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: to another and more probable legend, it was Burke who hurried the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: rupture, and stimulated Fox's jealousy of Shelburne. The Duke of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Richmond disapproved of the secession, and remained in the Government.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Sheridan also disapproved, but he sacrificed his personal conviction
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: to loyalty to Fox.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: If Burke was responsible for the break-up of the Government, then
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: he was the instigator of a blunder that must be pronounced not only
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: THE NEW MINISTRY--WARREN HASTINGS--BURKE'S PUBLIC POSITION
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: The six years which followed the destruction of the Coalition were, in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: some respects, the most mortifying portion of Burke's troubled career.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Pitt was more firmly seated in power than Lord North had ever been,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and he used his power to carry out a policy against which it was
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: impossible for the Whigs, on their own principles, to offer an
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: effective resistance. For this is the peculiarity of the king's first
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: victory over the enemies who had done obstinate battle with him for
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: nearly a quarter of a century. He had driven them out of the field,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: but with the aid of an ally who was as strongly hostile to the royal
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: system as they had ever been. The king had vindicated his right
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: against the Whigs to choose his own ministers; but the new minister
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: was himself a Whig by descent, and a reformer by his education and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: personal disposition.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Ireland was the subject of the first great battle between the ministry
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and their opponents. Here, if anywhere, we might have expected from
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke at least his usual wisdom and patience. We saw in a previous
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: chapter (p. 33) what the political condition of Ireland was when Burke
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: went there with Hamilton in 1763. The American war had brought about a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: great change. The king had shrewdly predicted that if America became
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: free Ireland would soon follow the same plan and be a separate state.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: In fact, along with the American war we had to encounter an Irish war
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: also; but the latter was, as an Irish politician called it at the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: time, a smothered war. Like the Americans, the Anglo-Irish entered
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: into non-importation compacts, and they interdicted commerce. The
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Irish volunteers, first forty, then sixty, and at last a hundred
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: thousand strong, were virtually an army enrolled to overawe the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: English ministry and Parliament. Following the spirit, if not the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: actual path, of the Americans, they raised a cry for commercial and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: legislative independence. They were too strong to be resisted, and in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: 1782 the Irish Parliament acquired the privilege of initiating and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: conducting its own business, without the sanction or control either of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the Privy Council or of the English Parliament. Dazzled by the chance
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of acquiring legislative independence, they had been content with the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in 1778, and with the removal of further restrictions by the alarmed
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: minister in the following year. After the concession of their
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: independence in 1782, they found that to procure the abolition of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: remaining restrictions on their commerce--the right of trade, for
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: instance, with America and Africa--the consent of the English
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: legislature was as necessary as it had ever been. Pitt, fresh from the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: teaching of Adam Smith and of Shelburne, brought forward in 1785 his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: famous commercial propositions. The theory of his scheme was that
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Irish trade should be free, and that Ireland should be admitted to a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: permanent participation in commercial advantages. In return for this
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: gain, after her hereditary revenue passed a certain point, she was to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: devote the surplus to purposes, such as the maintenance of the navy,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in which the two nations had a common interest. Pitt was to be
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: believed when he declared that of all the objects of his political
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: life this was, in his opinion, the most important that he had ever
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: engaged in, and he never expected to meet another that should rouse
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: every emotion in so strong a degree as this.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: A furious battle took place in the Irish Parliament. There, while
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: nobody could deny that the eleven propositions would benefit the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: mercantile interests of the country, it was passionately urged that
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the last of the propositions, that which concerned the apportionment
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of Irish revenue to imperial purposes, meant the enslavement of their
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: unhappy island. Their fetters, they went on, were clenched, if the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: English Government was to be allowed thus to take the initiative
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in Irish legislation. The factious course pursued by the English
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Opposition was much less excusable than the line of the Anglo-Irish
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: leaders. Fox, who was ostentatiously ignorant of political economy,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: led the charge. He insisted that Pitt's measures would annihilate
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: bring our maritime strength to the ground. Having thus won the favour
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of the English manufacturers, he turned round to the Irish Opposition,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and conciliated them by declaring with equal vehemence that the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: propositions were an insult to Ireland, and a nefarious attempt to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: tamper with her new-born liberties. Burke followed his leader. We may
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: almost say that for once he allowed his political integrity to be
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: him; he had warmly supported the Irish claims, and had lost his seat
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in consequence. The precise ground which he took up in 1785 was this.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: He appears to have discerned in Pitt's proposals the germ of an
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: extract revenue from the American colonies. Whatever stress may be
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

text: (1785), for stopping to pick up chaff and straws from the Irish
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: revenue instead of checking profligate expenditure in India.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Pitt's alternative was irresistible. Situated as Ireland was, she must
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: either be the subservient instrument of English prosperity, or else
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: she must be allowed to enjoy the benefits of English trade, taking at
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the same time a proportionate share of the common burdens. Adam Smith
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: had shown that there was nothing incompatible with justice in a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: contribution by Ireland to the public debt of Great Britain. That
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: debt, he argued, had been contracted in support of the government
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: established by the Revolution; a government to which the Protestants
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: for what he himself called the delirium of the preceding session, and

author: Morley, John

title: Burke

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke

author: Morley, John

author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: England and of Europe. An open mutiny had just been quelled in the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: fleet. There had been signs of disaffection in the army. In Ireland
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the spirit of revolt was smouldering, and in a few months broke out
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in the fierce flames of a great rebellion. And it was the year of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: political crime of Campo Formio, that sinister pacification in which
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: violence and fraud once more asserted their unveiled ascendancy in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Europe. These sombre shadows were falling over the western world when
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: a life went out which, notwithstanding some grave aberrations, had
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: made great spaces in human destiny very luminous.

text: CHAPTER X
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: BURKE'S LITERARY CHARACTER
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: A story is told that in the time when Burke was still at peace with
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the Dissenters, he visited Priestley, and after seeing his library
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and his laboratory, and hearing how his host's hours were given to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: experiment and meditation, he exclaimed that such a life must make
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: him the happiest and most to be envied of men. It must sometimes have
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: occurred to Burke to wonder whether he had made the right choice when
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: he locked away the fragments of his History, and plunged into the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: torment of party and Parliament. But his interests and aptitudes were
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: too strong and overmastering for him to have been right in doing
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: otherwise. Contact with affairs was an indispensable condition for
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the full use of his great faculties, in spite of their being less
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: faculties of affairs than of speculation. Public life was the actual
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: field in which to test, and work out, and use with good effect the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: moral ideas which were Burke's most sincere and genuine interests. And
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: he was able to bring these moral ideas into such effective use because
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: he was so entirely unfettered by the narrowing spirit of formula. No
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: man, for instance, who thought in formulae would have written the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: curious passage that I have already referred to, in which he eulogises
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: gin, because "under the pressure of the cares and sorrows of our
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: mortal condition, men have at all times and in all countries called
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in some physical aid to their moral consolation." He valued words at
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: their proper rate, that is to say, he knew that some of the greatest
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: facts in the life and character of man, and in the institutions of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: society, can find no description and no measurement in words. Public
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: life, as we can easily perceive, with its shibboleths, its exclusive
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: parties, its measurement by conventional standards, its attention to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: small expediencies before the larger ones, is not a field where such
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: characteristics are likely to make an instant effect.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Though it is not wrong to say of Burke that as an orator he was
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: transcendent, yet in that immediate influence upon his hearers which
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: is commonly supposed to be the mark of oratorical success, all the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: evidence is that Burke generally failed. We have seen how his speech
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: against Hastings affected Miss Burney, and how the speech on the Nabob
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of Arcot's debts was judged by Pitt not to be worth answering. Perhaps
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the greatest that he ever made was that on conciliation with America;
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the wisest in its temper, the most closely logical in its reasoning,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the amplest in appropriate topics, the most generous and conciliatory
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in the substance of its appeals. Yet Erskine, who was in the House
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: when this was delivered, said that it drove everybody away, including
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: people who, when they came to read it, read it over and over again,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and could hardly think of anything else. As Moore says rather too
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: floridly, but with truth,--"In vain did Burke's genius put forth
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: its superb plumage, glittering all over with the hundred eyes of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: fancy--the gait of the bird was heavy and awkward, and its voice
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: seemed rather to scare than attract." Burke's gestures were clumsy; he
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: had sonorous but harsh tones; he never lost a strong Irish accent;
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and his utterance was often hurried and eager. Apart from these
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: disadvantages of accident which have been overcome by men infinitely
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: inferior to Burke, it is easy to perceive, from the matter and texture
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of the speeches that have become English classics, that the very
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: qualities which are excellences in literature were drawbacks to the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: spoken discourses. A listener in Westminster Hall or the House of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Commons, unlike the reader by his fireside in the next century, is
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: always thinking of arguments and facts that bear directly on the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: special issue before him. What he wishes to hear is some particularity
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of event or inference which will either help him to make up his mind,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: or will justify him if his mind is already made up. Burke never
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: neglected these particularities, and he never went so wide as to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: fall for an instant into vagueness, but he went wide enough into the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: generalities that lent force and light to his view, to weary men who
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: cared for nothing, and could not be expected to care for anything, but
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the business actually in hand and the most expeditious way through it.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: The contentiousness is not close enough and rapid enough to hold the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: interest of a practical assembly, which, though it was a hundred times
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: less busy than the House of Commons to-day, seems to have been eager
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in the inverse proportion of what it had to do, to get that little
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: quickly done.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Then we may doubt whether there is any instance of an orator throwing
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: his spell over a large audience, without frequent resort to the higher
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: forms of commonplace. Two of the greatest speeches of Burke's time are
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: supposed to have been Grattan's on Tithes and Fox's on the Westminster
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Scrutiny, and these were evidently full of the splendid commonplaces
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of the firstrate rhetorician. Burke's mind was not readily set to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: these tunes. The emotion to which he commonly appealed was that
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: too rare one, the love of wisdom; and he combined his thoughts and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: knowledge in propositions of wisdom so weighty and strong, that the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: minds of ordinary hearers were not on the instant prepared for them.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: It is true that Burke's speeches were not without effect of an
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: indirect kind, for there is good evidence that at the time when Lord
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: North's ministry was tottering, Burke had risen to a position of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: first eminence in Parliament. When Boswell said to him that people
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: would wonder how he could bring himself to take so much pains with his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: speeches, knowing with certainty that not one vote would be gained by
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: them, Burke answered that it is very well worth while to take pains
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: to speak well in Parliament; for if a man speaks well, he gradually
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: establishes a certain reputation and consequence in the general
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: opinion; and though an Act that has been ably opposed becomes law, yet
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in its progress it is softened and modified to meet objections whose
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: force has never been acknowledged directly. "Aye, sir," Johnson broke
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in, "and there is a gratification of pride. Though we cannot outvote
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: them, we will out-argue them."
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Out-arguing is not perhaps the right word for most of Burke's
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: performances. He is at heart thinking more of the subject itself than
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of those on whom it was his apparent business to impress a particular
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: view of it. He surrenders himself wholly to the matter, and follows
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: up, though with a strong and close tread, all the excursions to which
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: it may give rise in an elastic intelligence--"motion," as De Quincey
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: says, "propagating motion, and life throwing off life." But then this
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: exuberant way of thinking, this willingness to let the subject lead,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: is less apt in public discourse than it is in literature, and from
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: this comes the literary quality of Burke's speeches.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: With all his hatred for the book-man in politics, Burke owed much of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: his own distinction to that generous richness and breadth of judgment
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: which had been ripened in him by literature and his practice in it.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Like some other men in our history, he showed that books are a better
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: preparation for statesmanship than early training in the subordinate
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: posts and among the permanent officials of a public department.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: There is no copiousness of literary reference in his works, such
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: as over-abounded in civil and ecclesiastical publicists of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: seventeenth century. Nor can we truly say that there is much, though
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: there is certainly some, of that tact, which literature is alleged to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: confer on those who approach it in a just spirit and with the true
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: gift. The influence of literature on Burke lay partly in the direction
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of emancipation from the mechanical formulae of practical politics;
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: partly in the association which it engendered, in a powerful
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: understanding like his, between politics and the moral forces of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: world, and between political maxims and the old and great sentences of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: morals; partly in drawing him, even when resting his case on prudence
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and expediency, to appeal to the widest and highest sympathies;
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: partly, and more than all, in opening his thoughts to the many
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: conditions, possibilities, and "varieties of untried being" in human
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: character and situation, and so giving an incomparable flexibility to
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: his methods of political approach.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: This flexibility is not to be found in his manner and composition.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: That derives its immense power from other sources; from passion,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: intensity, imagination, size, truth, cogency of logical reason. If any
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: one has imbued himself with that exacting love of delicacy, measure,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and taste in expression, which was until our own day a sacred
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: tradition of the French, then he will not like Burke. Those who insist
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: on charm, on winningness in style, on subtle harmonies and exquisite
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: suggestion, are disappointed in Burke; they even find him stiff and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: over-coloured. And there are blemishes of this kind. His banter is
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: nearly always ungainly, his wit blunt, as Johnson said of it, and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: very often unseasonable. We feel that Johnson must have been right in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: declaring that though Burke was always in search of pleasantries, he
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: never made a good joke in his life. As is usual with a man who has not
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: true humour, Burke is also without true pathos. The thought of wrong
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: or misery moved him less to pity for the victim than to anger against
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the cause. Then, there are some gratuitous and unredeemed vulgarities;
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: some images whose barbarity makes us shudder, of creeping ascarides
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and inexpugnable tapeworms. But it is the mere foppery of literature
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: to suffer ourselves to be long detained by specks like these.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: The varieties of Burke's literary or rhetorical method are very
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: striking. It is almost incredible that the superb imaginative
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: amplification of the description of Hyder Ali's descent upon the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Carnatic should be from the same pen as the grave, simple, unadorned
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: _Address to the King_ (1777), where each sentence falls on the ear
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: with the accent of some golden-tongued oracle of the wise gods. His
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: stride is the stride of a giant, from the sentimental beauty of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: picture of Marie Antoinette at Versailles, or the red horror of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: tale of Debi Sing in Rungpore, to the learning, positiveness, and cool
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: judicial mastery of the _Report on the Lords' Journals_ (1794), which
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Philip Francis, no mean judge, declared on the whole to be the "most
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: eminent and extraordinary" of all his productions. Even in the coolest
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and dryest of his pieces, there is the mark of greatness, of grasp, of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: comprehension. In all its varieties Burke's style is noble, earnest,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: deep-flowing, because his sentiment was lofty and fervid, and went
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: with sincerity and ardent disciplined travail of judgment. Fox told
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Francis Horner that Dryden's prose was Burke's great favourite, and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: that Burke imitated him more than any one else. We may well believe
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: that he was attracted by Dryden's ease, his copiousness, his gaiety,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: his manliness of style, but there can hardly have been any conscious
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: attempt at imitation. Their topics were too different. Burke had
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the style of his subjects, the amplitude, the weightiness, the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: laboriousness, the sense, the high flight, the grandeur, proper to a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: man dealing with imperial themes, the freedom of nations, the justice
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of rulers, the fortunes of great societies, the sacredness of law.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke will always be read with delight and edification, because in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the midst of discussions on the local and the accidental, he scatters
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: apophthegms that take us into the regions of lasting wisdom. In
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the midst of the torrent of his most strenuous and passionate
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: deliverances, he suddenly rises aloof from his immediate subject, and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in all tranquillity reminds us of some permanent relation of things,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: some enduring truth of human life or society. We do not hear the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: organ tones of Milton, for faith and freedom had other notes in the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: seventeenth century. There is none of the complacent and wise-browed
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: sagacity of Bacon, for Burke's were days of eager personal strife
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and party fire and civil division. We are not exhilarated by the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: cheerfulness, the polish, the fine manners of Bolingbroke, for Burke
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: had an anxious conscience, and was earnest and intent that the good
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: should triumph. And yet Burke is among the greatest of those who have
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: wrought marvels in the prose of our English tongue.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: The influence of Burke on the publicists of the generation after the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Revolution was much less considerable than might have been expected.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: In Germany, where there has been so much excellent writing about
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: _Staatswissenschaft_, with such poverty and darkness in the wisdom of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: practical politics, there is a long list of writers who have drawn
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: their inspiration from Burke. In France, publicists of the sentimental
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: school, like Chateaubriand, and the politico-ecclesiastical school,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: like De Maistre, fashioned a track of their own. In England Burke made
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: a deep mark on contemporary opinion during the last years of his life,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: and then his influence underwent a certain eclipse. The official Whigs
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: considered him a renegade and a heresiarch, who had committed the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: deadly sin of breaking up the party; and they never mentioned his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: name without bitterness. To men like Godwin, the author of _Political
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Justice_, Burke was as antichrist. Bentham and James Mill thought of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: him as a declaimer who lived upon applause, and who, as one of them
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: says, was for protecting everything old, not because it was good
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: but because it existed. In one quarter only did he exert a profound
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: influence. His maxim that men might employ their sagacity in
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: discovering the latent wisdom which underlies general prejudices and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: old institutions, instead of exploding them, inspired Coleridge, as
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: I have already said; and the Coleridgian school are Burke's direct
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: descendants, whenever they deal with the significance and the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: relations of Church and State. But they connected these views so
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: closely with their views in metaphysics and theology, that the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: association with Burke was effectually disguised.
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: The only English writer of that age whom we can name along with
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke in the literature of enduring power, is Wordsworth, that great
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: representative in another and a higher field, and with many rare
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: elements added that were all his own of those harmonising and
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: conciliatory forces and ideas that make man's destiny easier to him,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: through piety in its oldest and best sense; through reverence for
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the past, for duty, for institutions. He was born in the year of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: _Present Discontents_ (1770), and when Burke wrote the _Reflections_,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Wordsworth was standing, with France "on the top of golden hours,"
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: listening with delight among the ruins of the Bastille, or on the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: banks of the Loire, to "the homeless sound of joy that was in the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: sky." When France lost faith and freedom, and Napoleon had built his
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: throne on their grave, he began to see those strong elements which for
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: Burke had all his life been the true and fast foundation of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: social world. Wide as is the difference between an oratorical and a
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: declamatory mind like Burke's, and the least oratorical of all poets,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: yet under this difference of form and temper there is a striking
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: likeness in spirit. There was the same energetic feeling about moral
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: ideas, the same frame of counsel and prudence, the same love for the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: slowness of time, the same slight account held of mere intellectual
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: knowledge, and even the same ruling sympathy with that side of the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: character of Englishmen which Burke exulted in, as "_their awe
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of kings and reverence for priests," "their sullen resistance
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: of innovation" "their unalterable perseverance in the wisdom of
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: prejudice_."
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: The conservative movement in England ran on for many years in the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: ecclesiastical channel rather than among questions where Burke's
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: writings might have been brought to bear. On the political side
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: the most active minds, both in practice and theory, worked out the
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: principles of liberalism, and they did so on a plan and by methods
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: from which Burke's utilitarian liberalism and his historic
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: conservatism were equally remote. There are many signs around us that
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: this epoch is for the moment at an end. The historic method, fitting
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: in with certain dominant conceptions in the region of natural science,
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: is bringing men round to a way of looking at society for which Burke's
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: maxims are exactly suited; and it seems probable that he will be more
title: Burke
author: Morley, John

text: frequently and more seriously referred to within the next twenty years
title: Burke
author: Morley, John
